article.title: Grotesque Encounters in the Travel Writing of Henry James
article.author: Peter Rawlings
article.abstract: This essay examines the question of why Henry James was so addicted to the use of the word 'picturesque', especially in "Italian Hours", at a time when elsewhere it was regarded as an over-worked, commercial mode of conceptualization. James exploited, it is argued, the unstable boundary between the 'grotesque' and the 'picturesque' (as did Edgar Allan Poe found in the late eighteeth-century writings of William Gilpin, Uvedale Price, and others, partly for homoerotic purposes. In "Italian Hours", Ruskin's abhorrence of the 'low picturesque' is directly attacked as James revels in the erotic potential of ruin, decay, and mutilation, and that 'interchange and intorientation', as identified by Bakhtin, made possible by carnival.

article.author: ROBERT H. FOSSUM
article.publisher: Studies in the Novel, University of North Texas
article.abstract: Although lengthy critiques of contemporary writers were once a rarity, four recent books on Saul Bellowâby Tony Tanner, Keith Opdahl, James Clayton, and Irving Malinâare symptomatic of the current tendency to expend large amounts of critical energy on living authors, regardless of merit. Granted that Bellow, a fine novelist, deserves our attention, it is still questionable that he merits the detailed explications accorded him by three of these four books. Indeed, an examination of Opdahl's, Clayton's, and Malin's books suggests that if "close reading" is generally a virtue, it can also result in an overblown criticism unwarranted by its subject. (RHF)

article.title: "The Gods' Messenger and Secretary"? Thornton Wilder and the Classical Tradition
article.author: Raimund Borgmeier
article.journaltitle: International Journal of the Classical Tradition
article.abstract: The article attempts to give an overview and analysis of Thornton Wilder's relationship to the classical tradition. In the initial section, Wilder's background and his view of the role of the author are examined. It turns out that, in contrast to the predominant conception of a modern writer, he sees himself as a kind of poeta doctus who is examining the classical tradition. This is offered as a partial explanation for Wilder's surprisingly undervalued status as a literary author. The main part discusses the most significant works of Wilder in chronological order, concentrating on the classical elements. With The Woman of Andros, Wilder turns a Latin comedy into a modern novel. In Wilder's own plays, which clearly constitute his literary fame, he not only uses classical elements but also shows a basic affinity with the classical model. The Ides of March, Wilder's Caesar novel, depicts a complex portrait of the Roman dictator which even experts in this field find fascinating. The Alcestiad, though less successful on the stage, can be seen as one of the most significant adaptations of this classical myth in world literature. Even Wilder's last novels evince his proximity to the tradition originating in ancient Greece and Rome.

article.title: Recent Books Received
Chateaubriand's Use of Ossianic Language
article.author: Adrian H. Jaffe
article.abstract: The relationship between the language of Chateaubriand and that of the Ossianic poems not only serves as an excellent example of the important distinction between success and influence but also represents an example of true and ironic influence; true because the influence is perfectly clear, ironic because the influencing element, itself false, passes through an additional falsification in the process of translation and ultimately lodges where it has no intrinsic reason to be, at the head of one of the characteristic streams of French romanticism. The Ossianic poems are characterized not only by a tone of sadness and melancholy but are also distinguished from the traditional epic in that their episodes are fragmentary rather than parts of continuous Odysseys, with the result that it is impossible for the reader to concentrate upon the idiosyncratic character of the protagonist or to make any meaningful distinctions among the characters. The Ossianic series, therefore, appears to embody the ideal type of the noble savage whom Chateaubriand was later to depict in such heroes as Chactas, a savage who nonetheless has the ability of combining primitivism and contemplative faculties within the same individual. For these reasons, the American savages of Chateaubriand resemble the heroic, ancient Celts of Macpherson not only in character but in language as well, the language called "style sauvage," borrowed from that language which Macpherson had attributed to his Celtic heroes in the first place. This borrowing of an attribution is significant in the development of the genre, for one of the ultimate effects of Chateaubriand upon the development of French romanticism was the production of a strong association of the Ã©tat d'Ã¢me which we know as "mal du siÃ¨cle," with the framework of expression which he created from elements he took from Ossian via Macpherson, so that in this fashion did the ancient Scots survive, in ironic form, not only in the heart of French civilization but in the dignity of the speech of the romantic literary version of the American Indian. [A. H. J.]

article.author: Dean H. Keller
article.abstract: In 1829 a library, known as the "oxcart" library, was established under unusual circumstances at what is now North Olmsted in Ohio's Western Reserve. The collection originally contained approximately 500 volumes and was dispersed in the 1850s. Recent attempts to locate books in the original collection have resulted in a reconstructed collection numbering 166 volumes. These titles contribute to our knowledge of what readers on the frontier had available to them.

article.title: Larry Watson's "Montana 1948" and Euroamerican Representation of Native/Euroamerican History
article.author: Peter L. Bayers
article.journaltitle: Rocky Mountain Review of Language and Literature
article.abstract: Like other recent films and texts, Larry Watson's "Montana 1948" is preoccupied with the legacy of the U.S. conquest of Native America and the ongoing colonial relationship between the U.S. and Natives. But "Montana 1948" also self-consciously calls attention to the problems endemic to Euroamerican efforts to "revision" Euroamerican/Native history. Watson suggests that at best most Euroamericans engage in shallow, self-congratulatory pieties to relieve themselves of guilt in regard to Native America, and that when it comes to telling stories about Euroamerican interaction with Indians, these stories are mired in tired Indian representations that mystify material history and the ongoing colonial status of Natives in the United States. Through his flawed narrator, Watson underscores that Euroamericans must be more rigorously self-critical as they engage questions of representation and their own deeply held colonial desires when telling history.

article.title: About Mark Twain: Bibliographic Issue Number Three
signs of the times
Notes on a Comparative American Literary History
article.author: John O. McCormick
article.abstract: The history of American literary history shows that Americans, out of pseudoscientific bias, have regarded literary history not as a problem in aesthetics and thought but as a social and institutional problem. A debased Romanticism has produced mysticism, provincialism, and nationalism of interpretation, whÃ¼e historians working through symbol and myth tend to confuse a technique with a method. Literary history must be literary by concerning itself not with "fact" but with aesthetic fact, and it must be historical in recording the nature of the artist's technical problems together with his solutions. Comparative history is essential to the American to allow him to evade parochialism and to center upon aesthetic rather than sociological frameworks. The historian needs two sets of eyes: with one set to regard the specific work of the specific writer, in all of its "provable" aspects; with the other set to look beyond the objective to set up parallels, establish intellectual patterns, note the prominence of themes common to a national group or to international groups of writers, to look at many landscapes, at the other arts, and at the politics, the philosophy, and perhaps even at the sociology of events relevant to his period. [J. O. McC.]

article.title: Afterword: The Woman's Building Library and History
article.author: Emily B. Todd
article.abstract: This afterword reflects on the articles in this special issue on the Woman's Building Library and observes that each article argues that the books held in the library speak to tensions in women's roles and shifts in women's writing in late-nineteenth-century America. These same tensions evident in the library were also evident in the presentation of history and progress in the Woman's Building and throughout the fair. Seen against this backdrop of the Columbian Exposition and the Woman's Building, the historical fiction included in the library reveals how, in the years leading up to the fair, women themselves participated in presenting narratives of the nation's history.

article.title: "THE MARBLE FAUN" AND THE EDITING OF NINETEENTH-CENTURY TEXTS
article.author: JOHN FREEHAFER
article.publisher: Studies in the Novel, University of North Texas
article.abstract: The claim that the Centenary edition of Hawthorne is definitive and may serve as a model for editions of other nineteenth-century texts can be tested from The Marble Faun, a long and complex American text which was first printed in England, with many variations from Hawthorne's manuscript forms. A detailed examination of the emendations and methodology of the Centenary Marble Faun reveals tendentious and narrow analysis of internal bibliographic evidence, without regard to pertinent external evidence; inattention to pertinent linguistic and lexicographic evidence; excessive "normalization" of variants which often runs counter to Hawthorne's artistic and linguistic intentions; and adherence to a predetermined editorial practice which is too rigid and too narrow to encompass the full range of important editorial problems. Taken in conjunction with studies of the editing of other nineteenth-century texts, these findings suggest that Greg's theory of copy-text is not as easily applicable or as comprehensively useful in editing nineteenth-century texts as has sometimes been supposed. In particular, the Centenary editing relies too largely on technical bibliography, without enough attention to linguistic and esthetic questions. (JHF)

article.title: The Age of the Novel, the Age of Empire: Howells, Twain, James around 1900
article.author: Jonathan Arac
article.abstract: Around 1900 in the United States the novel was a dominant literary form, both a cultural institution, and an object within mass consumption. William Dean Howells, Mark Twain, and Henry James all participated in world literature as active cosmopolitans, and all also interacted with imperialism, at times oppositionally. With attention to these three authors' correspondence, public statements, and published writings, especially Twain's Following the Equator, the essay explores relationships between the institution of literature and the emerging category of the intellectual, as well as addressing the problem of world literature within world history.
